description.narrative: The Fair, Green and Global Alliance (FGG) aims to increase the power and decision-making influence of organised, mobilised and informed civil society, especially women, to advance fair and green trade and value chains. FGG believes that poverty, inequality and exclusion are caused by power asymmetries. We see the unprecedented power of capital over people and planet as the primary obstacle impeding realisation of fair and green trade and value chains. The FGG programme focuses on recalibrating power within the global architecture of trade and value chains by amplifying the voices of targeted rights-holders – small producers and traders, workers, fishers, rural and Indigenous peoples, religious and ethnic minorities, and migrants, especially the women and youth among them – who are practising, claiming or defending human rights and fair and green economic practices, and/or whose rights are being ignored, threatened or violated by corporations and/or governments. We aim to transform social relations so that these rights-holders’ voices are heard and heeded. FGG’s eight members (ActionAid, Both ENDS, Clean Clothes Campaign, IT for Change, Milieudefensie/Friends of the Earth International/Friends of the Earth Europe, Samdhana Institute, SOMO and the Transnational Institute) cooperate with some 1000+ partners and allies in our many worldwide networks to strengthen collective capacities to advance a common vision of fair and green trade and value chains.
Strategic Partnership FGG

title.narrative: private sector actors respecting human rights and the enviro
private sector actors respecting human rights and the enviro

description.narrative: By 2025, corporations and other private sector actors (including financiers/banks) act to respect human rights, women’s rights and environmental sustainability in their value chains
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative:
2022 We expect 1 European garment brand to implement recommendations on fair pay. We expect 1 European fossil fuel company to disclose information on transition plans and costs.
Our targets here are low because, given the focus areas of our work, we do not expect the private sector to take the needed actions voluntarily. Our focus is on securing legal and regulatory action to hold corporations to account. However, in some individual case work we expect companies to take action to remedy harms, including cases where we support partners to take action via non-judicial remedy processes.

2022 We expect 1 European garment brand to implement recommendations on fair pay. We expect 1 European fossil fuel company to disclose information on transition plans and costs.

However, in some individual case work we expect companies to take action to remedy harms, including cases where we support partners to take action via non-judicial remedy processes.

comment.narrative: 2022 We expect one tech company to support stronger due diligence by Big Tech. We expect one financial industry group to promote more caution around the use of ESG data as a tool to measure company impacts on climate, environment and human rights. comment.narrative: 2022 We expect at least 4 government actors in sub-Saharan Africa to support and promote recommendations to strengthen the UN Treaty process. We expect at least 3 EU governments (incl. NL) to support stronger provisions in the Digital Markets Act. We expect 1 government in EU (likely NL) to support measures to regulate fossil fuel companies in respect of how they are planning for energy transition. We expect 2 governments (incl. NL) in Europe to support our recommendations on mHRDD

description.narrative: By 2025, governments increase democratic decisionmaking and protection of human rights, women's rights and environmental sustainability in policies and practices affecting trade and value chains.
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative:
2022 Again, a lot of the work will be in the research phase in first part of 2022. We would expect some areas of work (some of the ISDS and ECT work specifically) to be implemented, but other areas of work will require a longer time horizon for implementation.
In 2022:
• We expect 1 key government actor in EU to commit to adopt recommendations on the Energy Charter Treaty. • We also expect that CETA will not be adopted by the NL • We expect EU customs data relevant to supply chains to be disclosed based on our longstanding recommendations.

description.narrative: # key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative:
2022 By end of 2022, we think it is realistic to have advanced to deeper support of the recommendations in 6 cases. In this we see the greatest potential to be on energy transition recommendations.
We expect key government actors in EU to support recommendations on changes to the Energy Charter Treaty. We expect key government actors in Latin America to support recommendations on a more just approach to energy transition and use of natural resources.

title.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sec
governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sec

description.narrative: By 2025, key actors (governments, government-backed institutions, private funders/investors) increase space and support for fair and green trade and value chains.
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative:
2022 We expect at least one EU policy actor to support alternative models for production of medicines, for instance by adopting and implementing stronger conditionality on public funding for development of medicines, but also the use of waivers for patents or a patent pool.
Our target is low in 2022 because energy transition work is likely to focus on research and advocacy will only happen later in the year. As such, adoption and implementation is more realistic for 2023 and beyond.

description.narrative: Civil society actors engaged in, claiming or defending human rights and fair and green practices have strengthened capacities for lobbying and advocacy, specifically: Knowledge, evidence and communication skills Capacities to mobilise constituencies Leverage on multiple (supra-national) pressure points Access to decision-making spaces
# targeted civil society actors that lobby and advocate for improved policies and practices in trade and value chains and advance fair and green practices based on capacities mutually developed

comment.narrative: 2022 Throughout 2022, we aim for 6 civil society actors to lobby and advocate for improvements and revisions to trade and investment agreements. This includes: work with CSOs in North Africa on trade deals with the EU which undermine communities’ rights to land; work with Indonesian CSOs on labour rights and trade; and work with CSOs in Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa on transition mineral supply chains. The focus will be on joint re-search and analysis, joint strategizing on advocacy across value chains and training.

2022 Throughout 2022, we aim for 6 civil society actors to lobby and advocate for improvements and revisions to trade and investment agreements. This includes: work with CSOs in North Africa on trade deals with the EU which undermine communities’ rights to land; work with Indonesian CSOs on labour rights and trade; and work with CSOs in Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa on transition mineral supply chains. The focus will be on joint re-search and analysis, joint strategizing on advocacy across value chains and training.

This includes: work with CSOs in North Africa on trade deals with the EU which undermine communities’ rights to land; work with Indonesian CSOs on labour rights and trade; and work with CSOs in Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa on transition mineral supply chains. The focus will be on joint re-search and analysis, joint strategizing on advocacy across value chains and training.

The focus will be on joint re-search and analysis, joint strategizing on advocacy across value chains and training.

description.narrative: # targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities contributing to and/or relevant for lobby and advocacy aiming at expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: 2022 Of these 10 CSOs, 2 will strengthen capacities that are relevant for their advocacy for civic space. SOMO will work with CSOs that are directly the target of restrictions on civic space in OPT and Myanmar to build their networks and capacity to respond to the threats.

description.narrative: # targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities for lobbying and advocacy

comment.narrative: 2022 We aim for 10 civil society actors from countries in Asia, Latin America, Middle East and North Africa and sub-Saharan Africa (including India, Indonesia, Kenya, Nigeria, Uganda, Myanmar, Argentina, Peru and Occupied Palestinian Territories) to strengthen their capacities to advocate for among other things improved corporate conduct and remedy for victims of corporate-related human rights abuses. To achieve this target, we engage in mutual capacity development activities such as joint strategizing, joint research and investigations networking and trainings.

To achieve this target, we engage in mutual capacity development activities such as joint strategizing, joint research and investigations networking and trainings.

To achieve this target, we engage in mutual capacity development activities such as joint strategizing, joint research and investigations networking and trainings.

description.narrative: # targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities relevant to advance gender justice

comment.narrative:
2022 Of these 10 CSOs, 2 will strengthen capacities that are relevant for their advocacy for gender justice. These CSOs, from Africa and Latin America, will strengthened their ability to carry out research using a gender lens, in particular in remedy cases where SOMO will support the CSOs to identify gender-differentiated impacts of corporate activity and to advocate for equality in access to remedy.
When communities suffer harm as a result of corporate activity, often efforts to secure a remedy fail to take account of gender and other facets of identity. Consequently, remedial action (such as paying compensation to male leaders or male heads of house-holds) can reinforce pre-existing inequality.

description.narrative: ​# of CSOs included in the FGG programme
Key actors (governments, private sector, media/other) put issues/recommendations raised by FGG on their agendas.
Key actors (governments, private sector, media/other) put issues/recommendations raised by FGG on their agendas.
# of instances in which the recommendation a key actor puts on its agenda aims to contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: 2022 From these 10 actors, we aim for 1 (EU) to put FGG recommendations on their agenda that contributes to civic space. These recommendations concern among other things civil society engagement in Indonesian trade policy development, in response to the Omnibus Bill, which restricts democratic decision-making.

description.narrative: # of instances in which the recommendation a key actor puts on its agenda aims to contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: 2022 From these 10 actors, we aim for 1 policymaker from Latin America to put an FGG recommendation on their agenda that contributes to gender equality. The recommendation will be derived from an analysis of the consequences of a chaotic transition for women in relation to control over resources and land in the context of energy transition.

2022 From these 10 actors, we aim for 1 policymaker from Latin America to put an FGG recommendation on their agenda that contributes to gender equality. description.narrative: ​# key actors (government, private sector, other) who put FGG policy/practice recommendations on their agendas (e.g. meetings, debates, media coverage)

comment.narrative:
2022 We expect that 10 key actors will put FGG recommendations on their agendas. This includes:
• At least one international organisation – most likely OECD - will include recommendations on access to medicines and on transition minerals on their agenda • National governments in Europe (incl. NL) will include recommendations on access to medication on their agenda • Government actors in EU, Latin America and African Union regions will put policy recommendations on transition minerals on their agenda • Government actors in EU will include recommendations on curbing monopoly power of Big Tech • Government actors in EU will put our recommendation our supply chain transparency on their agendas
